1) Not all risks have the same , e.g. if you chop veg with a sharp knife you risk cutting your
finger, but if you go scuba-diving you risk death. You’re much to cut your finger during
half an hour of than to die during half an hour of . But most people are happier
to accepta higher of an accident if the are and fairly .
2) People tend to be more willing to accept a risk if they to do something (e.g. go scuba diving),
compared to having the risk on them (e.g. having a nuclear power station built next door).
eople’s of risk (how risky they something is) isn’t always . They tend to
view activities as and activities as — even if that’s not the case.
For example, cycling on roads is often , but many people are happy to do it because it’s a
activity. Air travel is actually pretty , but a lot of people perceive it as .
eople may the risk of things with or effects, e.g. ionising radiation.
2) All hazards have a attached to them — this is the that the hazard will cause harm.
The risks of some things seem pretty , or we’ve known about them for a while, like the risk of
causing by polluting the atmosphere, or of having a when you’re travelling in a car.
4) arising from can bring , e.g. scientists are unsure whether
that are being used in cosmetics and suncream might be harming the cells in our bodies.
These risks need to be considered the of the technology, e.g. improved sun protection.
You can estimate the of a risk based on something happens in a big sample (e.g.
100 000 people) over a given (e.g. a year). For example, you could assess the risk of a driver
crashing by recording how many people in a group of 100
000 drivers crashed their cars over a year.
6) To make about activities that involve , we need to take into account the of
the hazard causing harm, and how the would be if it did. If an activity involves a
hazard that’s to cause harm, with if it does, it’s considered .
Not revising — an unacceptable exam hazard...
The world’s a dangerous place, but if you can recognise hazards, decide how to reduce their risks, and be happy to
accept some risks, you can still have fun. Just maybe don’t go skydiving with a great white shark on Friday 13th.
2) Part of planning an investigation is making sure that it’s .
3) You should always make sure that you all the hazards that you might encounter. Then you
should think of ways of from the hazards you’ve identified. For example:
1) Hazards from science experiments might include:
• , e.g. some bacteria can make you ill.
• , e.g. sulfuric acid can burn your skin and alcohols catch fire easily.
• , e.g. an unattended Bunsen burner is a fire hazard.
• , e.g. faulty electrical equipment could give you a shock.
• If you’re working with , always wear gloves and safety goggles. This will reduce
the risk of the acid coming into contact with your skin and eyes.
• If you’re using a , stand it on a heat proof mat.
This will reduce the risk of starting a fire.
You can ﬁnd out about potential hazards
by looking in textbooks, doing some
Internet research, or asking your teacher.
